item.title: docker-compose biolerplate
item.description: docker-compose boilerplate I don’t write docker-compose files that often. Usually there is only one docker-compose file per project, and when each project lasts for a couple of months… I tend to forget what the components of a docker-compose.yml file are. Here’s a boilerplate for a docker-compose.yml file: version: '3' services: app: build: . image: test/app:latest command: ["python3", "-m", "http.server", "9000"] environment: - SOME_ENV_VARIABLE=test volumes: - .:/app ports: - "9000:9000" depends_on: - mysql # https://hub.

item.title: Kubernetes
item.description: What is Kubernetes? Kubernetes (sometimes “abbreviated” to k8s) is a cluster management tool. A cluster is obviously a group of servers. Managing in this case relies on deployment (in containers), assigning and setting limits on resources like CPU and RAM, rolling back etc. Kubernetes is arguably the most popular infrastructure-management tool nowadays, which complies to the infractructure as code standard. How to learn kubernetes? The easiest way (IMHO) is by setiing up the simplest possible cluster locally on your own laptop.

item.title: heroku
item.description: 1. What is heroku and why would you use it? heroku is a platform which lets you run your django app on a server for free. Or at least this is how I use it ;) available at heroku.com 2. Curiosities deployment of your app is very simple. You write yor code, test it locally and push to the repo. The app is automatically deployed, as long as you set heroku to be one of your remote git repos.

item.title: vagrant
item.description: 1. What is vagrant and why would you use it? Vagrant let’s you setup and use virtual machines easily and quickly. You store full configuration of your VM in one text file (Vagrantfile), which makes it easily portable and trackable with git(hub). Vagrant may be useful for testing new tools and software. It’s more convenient than a traditional VM with a full GUI. 2.

item.title: docker
item.description: 1. What is docker and why would you use it? “In simpler words, Docker is a tool that allows developers, sys-admins etc. to easily deploy their applications in a sandbox (called containers) to run on the host operating system i.e. Linux.” Comparing to Python, it’s basically a virtualenv, but for the whole OS. Or this is some sort of a virtual machine; it’s a program, which lets you to encapsulate your software into its own, the most basic “OS” (known as “container” in docker’s world) and run it on any machine/server, which has docker installed;
